name: Owlboy
description: Owlboy is a story-driven platform adventure game, where you can fly and explore a brand new world in the clouds! Pick up your friends, and bring them with you as you explore the open skies, in one of the most detailed adventures of this era.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7/8/10/Vista Processor: Dual Core Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: Pixelshader 3.0 enabled graphics card(DirectX 10 capable graphics card) DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 600 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Basically, there is an alternate reality where Nintendo made a SNES 2 instead of the N64, and this was the best game ever made on that platform.

I will preface this review by saying that Owlboy is, overall, a good game that most people will enjoy. Looking at it objectively, it is at least a solid 6 or 7 out of 10. Those who value art and are able to get into the story are likely to rate it even higher. This review, however, is here to express the viewpoint of someone who did not particularly enjoy most of the game, and to explain why it might be one to avoid for similarly minded gamers.  In a nutshell, there is one thing Owlboy does amazingly, one thing it does atrociously, and a lot of perfectly adequate game in the middle. The pixel art is second to none. The game's lengthy development cycle is evident in every single piece of scenery, every character, every cutscene, and most importantly every gorgeous animation. The artists that worked on this game deserve nothing but praise, as they have managed to achieve something truly beautiful. I have seen a number of people compare this game to Ori and the Blind Forest, and in the art department that comparison is certainly an apt one. Ori may still be the king of gaming visuals overall, but Owlboy steals the crown when it comes to pixel art.  Where Owlboy does not compare favourably to something like Ori is in the gameplay, and here comes my greatest nitpick. I say nitpick, because for many people this will likely be much less of a problem than it was for me. If you're a gamer who shares this particular niggle, however, you'll understand immediately how one seemingly small problem can all but ruin an otherwise enjoyable experience:  I am not at all exaggerating when I say that I never once played Owlboy for longer than five minutes without the game wresting control away from me. Most of the time the interruptions were far more frequent.  Whether it is for a character to deliver a line of dialogue, a cutscene to occur, a door to open, or some other scripted event to play out, Owlboy delights in dragging you out of the moment with constant jarring interruptions that destroy the pacing and flow of the experience. The vast majority of these are completely unnecessary. Even many of the lines of dialogue do not require a pause in the gameplay for them to be delivered. There are moments in the game where characters talk, doors open, and scripted sequences occur *without* taking control away from the player, and they all work perfectly.  The most egregious examples of the above are when otherwise intense boss fights are interrupted multiple times for lines of completely unnecessary dialogue to be delivered and phase transitions to occur. I cannot stress enough just how much of a toll this takes on the pacing of the gameplay. Intense moments fall flat, brain-tickling puzzles become annoying, and any section you have to repeat more than once becomes infinitely more tiresome thanks to the arbitrary interruptions. This problem permeates every aspect of Owlboy, dragging the entire experience down and souring a lot of the game's goodness. It's such a shame to see, especially after such a long development cycle, because all of it would have been completely avoidable with more awareness of how to create good pacing in gameplay.  Besides the above, most of Owlboy falls into solid 'good' territory. There are annoyances here and there, but also plenty of cool moments and clever bits of design to counterbalance them. There's no map or objective indicator, which can at times be a frustration in a metroidvania-esque game like this, but for the most part the levels are elegant and direct enough to avoid too much confusion. The bosses are very fun and satisfying when they aren't interrupted too much, and all of them are unique and memorable. The story is just fine, though nothing to write home about. There's enough emotion and drama to hit plenty of people right in the feels, but in a world where we have games like Undertale or The Walking Dead, the writing ultimately comes across as pretty middle of the road. There's passion and heart in it, however, and while the dramatic beats didn't really have enough substance for me, Owlboy at least puts far more effort into its story than the majority of games out there. The soundtrack similarly hits the correct emotional beats, but none of the tracks ever stuck in my mind for long or made me want to look them up on youtube afterwards.  Core gameplay-wise, again, it's just fine. Shooting is fun and punchy. The dash feels good. General movement is okay, but doesn't have much satisfying momentum or weight to it. You don't soar like a bird so much as just drift around the screen. There are a couple of ill-considered platforming segments that do not feel good to play at all, but they're few and far between. Some abilities and their associated controls feel responsive and well-implemented, others are a little finicky. Most of the game's puzzle gimmicks are enjoyable if a little shallow. There's really not a whole lot to talk about in this regard. Owlboy plays just fine. It does what it needs to do. Not great, not bad, just good enough and largely competent.  In regards to difficulty, Owlboy is quite forgiving without ever feeling too easy. There's just enough challenge to make beating bosses and clearing areas satisfying. Some bits will be tough for players who are less experienced with the genre, but it's by no means a hardcore game. It hits the middle of the spectrum incredibly well.  In summary, I was someone who hoped Owlboy might be a real game of the year candidate for me, in much the same way Ori and the Blind Forest was. Unfortunately, while Owlboy looks every bit the part, it doesn't quite stand up in the gameplay department. The constant interruptions were an ever-present problem, and everything else, while consistently above-average, rarely wowed me in the same way similar titles have. I made sure to finish the game so as to piece together an informed opinion on it, but at times it was something of a slog.  If you're not picky about interruptions to gameplay, Owlboy is almost certainly worth the buy. There's a lot of great stuff in there, and if you love good art then it's worth the price tag for that alone. If you're a fan of the gameplay in titles like Ori and the Blind Forest, Shovel Knight or Freedom Planet, however (and if you're keenly aware of *why* their gameplay works so well), Owlboy may be something of a disappointment.

Think Secret of Monkey Island meets Megaman meets a lot of good feelings.  The story and characters of this game are unforgettable. Even if it appears short, it's seeping with rich and cherishable moments.  The time it takes you to play this game, doesn't matter.  If you do play this game, take your time to enjoy the scenery. A LOT of effort was put into it.  I can't recommend this game enough.

Try to ignore the hype around how long the game took to make, it doesn't really show in any area besides the quality of the visuals. Owlboy is a decent game dressed up with really gorgeous pixel art. The gameplay lacks a strong central mechanic, the controls aren't great, the movement speed is just slow enough that traversal feels really tiresome, and I always had the feeling that the level and creature designs were never really playing to the mechanics' strengths.  Story-wise, it's an okay effort, but nowhere near what the game or some of the reviews would have you believe. I always felt like it was trying to puff up what was in actuality a pretty small package. At the first campfire sequence before you've reached the Owl Temple, Geddy talks about how it feels like they're on a real adventure. I could think of similar scenes in other games and mediums where there was a real sense of travel and reflection, but all I could think of was 'what? we're doing this now? we've only been out of the first town for less than 5 minutes'. It was a nice looking scene but it really showed the distance between what I was feeling and what the game wanted me to feel.  There were some nice character moments scattered about but, like the story, the cast is not as timeless or loveable as the game might want you to think. They're cutesy and inoffensive but they all felt a bit thin. The only moment that really grabbed me was listening to the old man from the hot spring reminiscing in the ruins. I wished the main characters impressed on me in the same way.  Ultimately, the game is okay. I'm marking it as not recommended to reflect a level of overall personal dissatisfaction, but I think the general praise implies that it resonates in some way with a lot of people. I really wish the game was as good as it wants to be.

Nine years is a large chunk of anybody’s lifetime, for those of us lucky to see a century, it’s almost a tenth of the precious, finite time we get to spend on this planet. I’ve been following the progress of this game since the first few morsels were public and admit to having forgotten about the game several times until inevitably finding more little delicious crumbs to follow until arriving at the 1st of November and a metaphorical cake, responsible for the delicious line of crumbs that preceded it waited to be eaten.   I sat there like a mad man, refreshing the store page every five seconds until I was finally allowed to pick up my fork (controller) and dig in (buy and play the game!) Until at last some wonderful music and gorgeous pixel art made way for the menu buttons, the new game started and I started to take the first bite.  After a brief and somewhat emotionally uncomfortable introduction to basic mechanics, the game proper began in a lush, warm room, I stayed here for five minutes mesmerised by the level of mastery the artist had shown through animation, colour palette and precision of pixel placement. Everything looked as it should, as the artist had no doubt spent hours meticulously on this single interior, this prospect left me feeling both excited and somewhat flabbergasted as to what might be waiting for the majority of the game that was waiting for me.  Outside, the incredible visuals began to be accompanied by some understated but catchy music, fading and acquiring new layers to its depth as the area was explored, and explore I did. I spent a good hour just playing, interacting with objects, smashing pots for the glittering coins within and hitting flowers before watching them grow back. It might be an overstatement to say that small details like this are what make good games great but what it shows is a deeper level of understanding of the symbiotic substance that is a video game. Video games are a composition of audio, visual and active interaction; the greatest challenge of any game designer or indeed, member of any games design team is to anticipate player action, it may seem stupid but by placing a seemingly small and insignificant flower for me to repeatedly lop the head off of is testament to the level of thought that has gone into building this lush, interactive world to explore.   The devil is in the details, when you move slightly a cloud of dust forms at your feet, when you flap and roll, the air visually moves behind you and it all contributes to making the movement feel dynamic. Audio, visual and interactivity composed to make even the simple act of movement fun and engaging, which is a relief because as this is primarily platforming and exploration you’re going to be doing that a lot!   Quite a few critics have, in my opinion, unfairly described OwlBoy as having a “retro pixel art aesthetic”. There is no appeal to retro-activity to be found in the sublime pixel pushing of this artist but simply a love, understanding and desire to show the gaming community the brilliance of pixel art as a form of visual art in and of itself. There were so many occasions where I sat there in sheer awe of the level of detail being presented to me in one of the harshest, most technically difficult mediums to present such things. Any person can pick the pencil tool in paint and draw an isometric cube, provided they clicked one pixel at a time this could be described as pixel art but that would be the same as getting someone to paint a portrait of their dog in oils and calling them Rembrandt.   OwlBoy is a master-class in pixel art; it is the interactive equivalent of going to see the finest works of art at La Louvre in that it showcases the medium of pixel art in a manner so far unmatched in any indie game thus far and I would put it on a level equal to some of the greatest pixel work done in video games, ever.  As mentioned earlier the visual is accompanied by some of the most whimsical, brilliantly executed musical pieces that I have heard for some time, everything is meticulous here, considered and there’s no better way to understand that to simply play it yourself. The visual and audio contribute to making each and every area feel unique, hand crafted and a pleasure to explore.  The ability to fly is such a huge and wondrous ability, usually limited to the final parts of many action-driven platformers, so it is such an ingenious twist to gimp the main characters abilities in the realm of combat very rarely can you do anything but dodge or defend when playing as Otus (the titular owlboy) alone. Luckily the designers were kind enough to supply you with three very different (mechanically and characteristically) friends to grab hold of your feet and offer their projectile shooting abilities, each has their own uses, from providing a piercing rapid fire to cover most basic enemies and weaker structures; to huge bursts of musket fire to incinerate. Not once do you feel like a character is merely there for the sake of it, they have been designed and the world and all of its dirty little secrets has been designed around both your ability to fly and their ability to help you to.   Speaking of dirty little secrets, there’s quite a few, hidden walls to find that usually contain some point of interest such as chests or coins. At one point I discovered a secret, only to return later and realise it held and even bigger one. Discovering these things always feels organic, as though you were meant to and that speaks volumes of the game as a whole to be honest, everything feels as though it was MEANT to be that way, it feels crafted, designed out of a labour of love. There will never be coins you can miss, they’ve been placed in areas that you can access after exploring an area; such is the level of foresight possessed by the creators.   The narrative, story and plot are all wonderfully executed; you’re always kept guessing and there’s enough mystery to fuel a fan base who will inevitably be making discussion threads about why certain things are said or done. The pacing feels tight and considered, not once did I feel the story was rushed or there was too much exposition thrown at me at once. Ultimately, once more, everything felt like it had a purpose, as though it belonged for a reason greater than simply “because it can”.   I’ve spent 20 hours exploring in this game and I don’t feel like single second of my time was wasted in terms of the main content of the game, there’s one mini game whose inclusion seems rather odd and out of place but this would be the singular negative in an otherwise brilliantly executed piece of art. OwlBoy rewards you for exploring, for interacting and provides some of the greatest pixel art I’ve ever seen in a game together with some top notch music.   I’d like to take this opportunity to thank the development team, thank you for spending the most precious thing you have in your life, your time, for making what has been a wonderfully fulfilling experience. You are all amazing and if I were rich enough I’d buy the game a million times over.

This game pays tribute to classic SNES aventure games in much the same way that Spielberg payed tribute to the adventure movies during the golden age of cinema. This is the 'Raider of the Lost Ark' of video games.

This game is a hoot.  Really though I have to say Owlboy is one of the best-looking games on Steam. Right from the get-go I could see all the painstaking detail that went into this game to make it as gorgeous as it is, from the charming character expressions to the environments that really draw you into the world of the game. Aside from beholding the magnificent visuals, the game itself is a lot of fun! Keep in mind I went into this without any expectations and found myself surprised at the quality of the puzzles and level design. Oh, and the MUSIC is so vibrant and does an amazing job at reflecting the tone of the game through it's various stages. If you're looking for a game that'll make you smile or just really like owls then I'd definitely say the price is well worth it, even if you just want to give it a shot I'm confident a masterpiece game like this will rarely, if ever, disappoint.

Been playing all day since release and really enjoying this adventure! This is pixel art at is finest. The gameplay is top notch and the story and characters intriguing! Don't have time to write more, need to get back to the game.  Buy and play!

Not the longest game, nor the most complicated, nor the hardest, but Owlboy was visually and aurally one of the best games I've ever played.  The gameplay is relatively simple, but satisfying, and some parts required multiple redos - as a person who generally enjoys coasting through games and experiencing them, this is preferable to a particularly difficult retro game ala Mega Man.   The story started off slow but a twist in the first half really caught my attention and I played through to the end, really enjoying the interactions between characters in this little world that had been created.  Despite the relatively low playtime/dollar ratio (the time I have now, 9 hours, is having completed the game with some side content, though not close to all of it) I could not recommend this game more highly to anyone who sees it and at the first glance is interested.
I don't leave reviews often, and to be fair, this is the first one I've ever left.  But boy oh boy, if you only ever have enough money to spend for ONE game. Make sure you spend it on this.

A work of art! I didn't think I'd see another retro platformer as good as Shovel Knight for YEARS but Owlboy has proven me wrong.   Amazing music score, rich story and complex yet fun gameplay makes this game a definite must have in any person's game library.
This game is fun. Like really really fun. From the visuals to the gameplay. Everything is so polished that it puts Nintendo to shame. Well done, D-Pad!

PLEASE NOTE: the following is my review of the game and MY opinion about the game. If you don't feel the same way that I do, please consider that this is only my opinion, and that it's completely fine if you don't agree. It won't change my mind.   ...Where do I even begin with this game?...  Owlboy. You don't think much of a title like that right away...But then this game pulled me in.   I heard about this game from VideoGameDunkey, in his PAX video I believe. I saw the art and thought it was intriguing, as I am a big fan of art, whether it be music or visual art, or otherwise. Seeing that the game had come out recently, I bought it and started playing it. What I found was a great journey of many emotions and many wonders. I honestly felt like a child again playing this game.   Owlboy pulled me in right from the start. I was interested in the characters, their plights, and I wanted to like everybody. And honestly, I did. I can safely say I like EVERY character in this game, good or bad, for different reasons.  The art and the music is just simply breathtaking. I found myself getting lost exploring this world the whole way through. Quirky characters, funny items (play the game you'll understand), and the journey that was taken with friends. Owlboy makes you love every single friend you make in this game.   Now, this all might be fine and good, but what about THE GAMEPLAY? I can assure you, the gameplay is great. It blends so many elements of metroidvanias, zelda-esque puzzle-solving, and platforming together seamlessly into one nice ball of fun. The bosses are all exciting, encourage solving another puzzle, and keep you gripped on the story. Play this game for about thirty minutes, and you'll see what I mean.  D Pad Studios, if you guys are reading this, you spent a great 9 years making this game. I can't thank you enough. PLEASE, I IMPLORE YOU, consider porting this game to consoles, as other people should experience this wonderful masterpiece of an indie game. Any other developers that are out there playing this or considering this competition in any way, THIS IS HOW YOU DESIGN A VIDEO GAME. So many game developers today lose sight of how to design in an effort to rush a product out to grab cash quick. This game has been in development 9 years, and it's probably the best game I've ever played. No hyperbole, and no sarcasm.  In conclusion, Owlboy is a fantastic journey through a beautiful world with rich scenery, a great soundtrack, WONDERFUL characters and an absolutely wonderful story that will have you on the edge of your seat the whole way through. My only gripe with this game, is that I wish I had more.   This game gets a 10/10 from me, and that's a hard score to come by from me these days. Thank you so much for making Owlboy, developers. All I want to do is jump back in and play the story again.

Spectacular, Amazing, and extremely fun to play.  The absolutely beautiful 32-bit graphics made me feel nostalgic all the way through the game, and put detail and life throughout every area that you explore. The emotional, and occasionally touching cutscenes really do make you care about the wonderful, and diverse characters that you meet. The gameplay mechanics were perfect in almost every aspect. Everything comes together in this incredible adventure that you have with Otus.  It's not hard to tell that this game has had a lot of tender love and care put into it throughout its long development cycle of nine years, because this is one of the best games I've played this year.  100/10 An experience that you simply cannot miss.
One of the best games in a long time! Great story. Great gameplay. Music is excelent! Buy this game. NOW! Stop reading this! BUY IT!
Can't recommend this game more. Worth the price of admission, considering the writing, art, and beautiful orchestra. An instant favorite!

Owlboy is beautiful. Don't be put off by price tags, these $25 is worth more than most other games you've bougth at even higher tags.  To me Owlboy is a story of friendship, the ability to look past mistakes and what you can achieve together. And throwing monkeys in lava. The different characters have so much personality to them, shown in both dialouge and expressions.  While the story itself can be completed fairly quickly there's still a lot to explore and find. Spending time finding coins for the Buccanary Shop is totally worth the time spent simply for the amazing dialouges you'll get from it. There are secrets to be found as well, and are well rewarded with various lore events so I do recommend spending time outside the main story itself.   A lot of love has gone into making this game, to make sure we can love it in return. And I absolutely loved the time I spent on this game.

Owlboy is an experience for your eyes, ears, and brain. The detail of the pixel art and animations are out of this world; they have no right to exist in our existence. I found myself wanting to stop progressing with the story just to listen to the newly found area's music. It doesn't treat you like an idiot with its puzzles, it instead subtly nudges you in the correct direction. Please support a game like this that has so much love and care put into it.  Update: Nominated

Owlboy, How do i describe Owlboy, It's an amazing platformer with alot of character's you can't stop loving. this game gives you everything you want in a game, Beautiful sprites, An amazing story that isn't like that Call of duty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t here you get a game with almost everything you want, I almost cried through most of the game, It's amazing and i don't regret one bit buying this game and i think a €22 pricetag fits this perfectly thanks D-pad studio's for an amazing experience

It's beautiful, relatively easy to play through, has enjoyable music, and characters that are pretty well-written.  The ending was slightly disappointing, but the rest of the game is so good, it doesn't really matter. The message is still good.

Great game; been enjoying it a lot so far. Pixel art looks superb and the music is outstanding. Obviously, no game is perfect. I accidentally experienced a game-breaking bug during the final boss battle in the Owl Temple. While escaping the giant mechanic-frog-like creature, I got hit and phased through the ceiling. This resulted in me being able to escape the corridor and fly away, which lead to some scary graphical glitches.

I was browsing my steam store and rolled over OwlBoy a couple of times now because I'm usually not into 2D side scrollers of any kind really. But I decided to give it a go and holy cow this game gave me a wild ride. Right from the get go you are introduced to a cast of loveable characters and absolutely beautiful polish.The bosses and puzzles are challenging and rewarding once you figure out how to do them.It only gets better and better as the story goes along. After finishing the story I could feel the amount of love in care that's been put into it and I would highly reccomend this game to anyone even if you would think this game isn't up your alley.
This game is a good nut.
A well-paced and thoughtful 2D platformer with beautiful pixel graphics and quirky fun characters, A lot of love and hardwork went into this game, and I'm glad I got the chance to play it.

This is an amazing game! Probably the biggest thing I like is authentic atmosphere. But really, all aspects of the game are good or great.  Overall score: 9/10. Difficulty: Medium. Graphics: 10/10. It's the best pixel graphics I ever seen.  Music: 10/10. The soundtracks are nice and original.  Story: 8/10. Interesting beginning and middle part, nice plot twist in the middle, but somewhat boring ending. Gameplay: 10/10. Game has interesting mechanics, when most of your abilities are provided by your companions, which you can carry and switch between. Each companion has unique set of abilities, and the game often requires you to choose the right companion for the situation. Level design: 9/10. Each level introduces new gimmicks and enemies, which made levels interesting to play and not getting boring. There are few segments that are slightly repetitive though. Darkness gimmick was quite tedious. Also, I expected final fight to be harder.
Owlboy perfectly melds adventure and exploration with free-roaming duel stick shooting mechanics.

A game that deserves all the praise it gets, and with Steam Train finally covering this game, I hope others can see just how amazing a story about an Owlperson saving his homeland from pirates really is.  Highly recommended.
10 years... worth the wait
Great game, tight controls, beautifully crafted pixel art. Sad, but engaging story, especially if you take the time to fly around and discover more and more of the backstory.
One of the best platformers ever made!  10/10

9 years to make with an hour of game play for every year. Way worth the cost. Amazing music, great gameplay, great story, and breath taking pixel graphics. Can't get enough of this game and I think I'll replay it a couple of times.
Superb art, nice gameplay and music. The devs deserve all your support on this one.
to keep things short This game has to be one of the best games of 2016 in my opinon
Wonderful game. I've played and finished it twice, bought it to write the review. The ending is a bit disappointing, but it's a very good game nonetheless. :)

While the game has some flaws, the overall experience of the game was fantastic. The art is just stunning, and flying around is a joy. The puzzles in the game could have used a bit more complexity, but were fun regardless. A definite must have for those who enjoy shorter indie titles.

Owlboy is fantastic. If you really need more than that, read on.  Are you a real gamer? Are you someone who is serious about the art and love of videogames. Do you identify as a gamer? Maybe you've developed a game or game assets, produced fan art, competed at some level, or you have a serious hobby in video games.  If you are, the you will understand what I mean when I say that sometimes a game comes around that you need to play. A game that you will compare other games to. A game that will fill a spot in your list of accomplishments or meet a need that's been building inside of you. A game that is both nostalgic and fresh and fun.   You need to play owlboy. It's not because it's a perfect game. It isn't. Owlboy is special. It's a rare, well done, beautiful game and you will be lesser of your craft if you miss out on playing it.  Controls are very good, tight, responsive, and easy to master. I played using a controller and I recommend it. Graphics are absolutely gorgeous 2-d sprites. Sounds and music are pleasant and mood setting, they are done very well. Story is gripping. I will admit, it's not for everyone and the ending may be a tough pill for some - but overall I was entertained and glad to have seen it through (ensure you finish the sidequests to get all the details).  I rate Owlboy a 10/10. A perfect score doesn't mean a perfect game, it means that to me Owlboy represents the best of what is available right now in video games.

The only downside I can think of, is the bullsheit hidden rooms. Sure, its nice for all the nutters out there.  But as a casual gamer having to grind your cute little owl face on every surface, in the vague hopes of suddenly falling through an invisible wall. Not so much.  But all in all, it's as clear as Ra's glowing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, just how much love and efford was put into this game. Definitely recommend! Think of it as Zelda with wings.
Gorgeous, charming and a all-round joy to play.
Amazing game. Beautiful artwork and soundtrack as well as an interesting story. I havent finished it quite yet but I definitely will (which is more than I can say for most of the games that I own).
What a beautiful, fantastic game. Even my four year old daughter is an instant fan!
So nostalgic & awesome. Don't think more about it, buy the game now!

Ok, lets go to September 2015, I just got a new pc to play AAA games like Witcher 3  Then Undertale swept me away and it became one of my favorite games  Now it's November 2016, I just upgraded my graphics card for games like Dishonored 2  And now Owlboy is pulling me in with it's spectacular art, music, and charm  Not even mad 10/10

+++ Graphics  Incredible work on graphics. Varied environments make for exciting exploration.  ++ Music  Would be 3+, but I feel some of the transitions in music can be a little awkward at times.  ++ Story  Very good story with likeable characters. I won't spoil anything though.  + Gameplay  It's fun, but feels slow at times. Somewhat easy. I find myself mashing the roll button to get around quicker. I enjoy the collection aspect for money, as it gives the player motivation to explore more, as well as giving a clear goal to completionists.  - Level Design  Not a big fan of some of the levels. They feel a little maze-like in some situations. I think a simple map may help, but I feel that might take away from some of the exploration aspect. There is a dark section in the game which really made this score drop.  Overall ++   Incredible graphics and great music, very immersive, with a good story. Gameplay is pretty fun, really enjoyable if you enjoy casual exploration. The levels sometimes feel bland (just the way you progress through them, the art on them is amazing), and sometimes a little repetetive.  I'd say for $25 it's worth it for a player who loves exploration and story.
Beautiful, charming, magical. This is the stuff that Nintendo used to deliver back in their good days, you totally know what I'm talking about.

Absolutely beautiful game that is absolutely mediocre. What a let down. The developers made a wonderful world with great music and atmosphere, only to fill it with boring block puzzles and monotonous combat, over and over and over and over.   Buy it for $5, nothing more.

This game is fantastic! The visuals, the music, the gameplay, the story are all engrossing and brilliant. I had played 4 hours of it and had hardly noticed the time!   Highly reccomended, and well worth the ~$25.   One note, it's much easier to play with a mouse and keyboard than a gamepad, IMHO.
I get a lot of Zelda Wind Waker vibes from this, and that's a good thing.

This game came out two days before my birthday, and I cant imagine a better gift. It feels like playing Zelda Link to the Past for the first time. Everything oozes style and craft and love. This is my game of the year, and unless somethiung truly amazing comes out next year will be my game of 2017. A true classic up there with any Miyamoto project. Nintendo should give these people a job
A brilliant game in all aspects. Solid gameplay, story, beautiful art and soundtrack awake nostalgic feelings.
would owl again

THIS GAME IS INCREDIBLE   Satisfying gameplay. Beautiful art. Really captures adventure and has a kind of 'Miyazaki' sense of wonder.   One downside - My computer turned off mid-game right after I reached a save point. I loaded it back up and my save file was gone. I had exited the game and picked up from where I left off prior to this. Dont know what happened.  but overall (this technical issue aside) i highly recommend this game.

Owlboy an almost perfect game in my opinion. Visually it looks stunning. The soundtracks can evoke a variety of emotions depending the the scene. I did face few glitches and there was a frustration mission. I loved the game to bits. Otus though mute is immediately likable and his companions too have their distinct personalities. There is a diverse range of locations to visit and explore. Though there aren't many different types of enemies there are quite a healthy number of boss fights spread throughout the game. It keeps the game challenging and I never got bored exploring the beautiful locations.   If you are reading this review I assume that you were curious enough about the game and scroll down to the reviews. It is completely worth the purchase and you won't be disappointed.

Owl boy is like that blonde cheerleader from high school: you wait ten years for your chance to be with her, but, when the time comes, she's nothing but a pretty face. Owl boy is absolutely gorgeous. I'd read reviews, watched youtube videos, etc., and was well aware going in how pretty it was supposed to be. Nothing prepared me for the first zoomed out shot of the overworld. Jaw literally dropped.   Then I started playing. Then I started waiting for it to be good. Then I started praying it would evenutally become good. It never did.   Just like the blonde cheerleader, owl boy is gorgeous and overflowing with charm, but it doesn't have a single inch of depth. 90% of the game is spamming 'roll' to get around the map and holding the left mouse button. That's it. It never advances beyond that. Even the intermittent stealth scenes are just spamming 'roll' to move from obstacle to obstacle. That's it. No strategy, no skill, no challenge. The occasional puzzle and loads of spam.   The emotional payoff of having a mute, mostly unrelatable protagonist doesn't payoff until the last scene. It's not worth 7 hours of playtime for a one minute cutscene of emotion.   I hate every word of this review because I wanted so badly to enjoy this game and be able to support the indie devs putting in the hard work to make games we crave. But, sadly, this is even more lifeless than AAA action FPS games. I would not call this adventuring, platforming, or even 'tactical twin stick' as I have seen it described.   D-Pad studio obviously has talent and knows how to make a game look good. I think they just forgot gameplay along the way. I want to say they forgot to have their game beta-tested for the 'fun-factor' before committing to it, but I doubt that's the case.

In fact I went to bed the night after I played it, woke up, then went the ENTIRE NEXT DAY before I remembered 'oh yeah I played Owlboy didn't I, I should refund it.' It was that forgettable. I have never played a game I literally forgot the next morning; they're either too good or too bad. This one was just too mediocre.  'But you only played for 47 minutes!' True! To which I defend myself by saying I went to a friend's house for the weekend and observed as he played it there, since he told me to buy it. At no point did I think 'I should buy the game again.' The gameplay is generic, the levels are generic, the story tries and fails to be meaningful, and the only redeeming quality are the graphics. It pains me that such cool graphics are in a game so utterly boring as this one.  I'm also annoyed at some reviews claiming this is the best platformer of 2016. You spend a majority of your time FLYING, which means you CAN'T PLATFORM. Child of Light had this issue. This game is not a platformer, and it barely qualifies as a puzzle game since the puzzles are laughable.  I don't want to say I didn't stay for the ending... Art: 9/10  Basically the best pixel art I've ever seen. However, some animations felt slightly under par, particularly on some party members.  Music: 9/10  Actually really really good.  Gameplay: 6/10  My two biggest issues with the game as a whole are the enemies and movement mechanics. The bosses are way too easy, I only died to the final boss once and most other bosses I did not die at all on. There are no enemies outside of bosses that were a real threat, outside of 'trap' enemies, and the static obstacle Pirates. The greatest depth in movement is tapping B every half second, or much later on (for basically a single level), using a grappling hook thing.   This game I feel would be greatly improved by adding extra abilities to the player throughout the game, and having more varied and difficult enemies, as well as making the bosses more difficult. However, this is coming from a person with 3000 hours in the Dark Souls series, so take some of that with a grain of salt.  In addition to those issues, the levels often seem very simple. All of them are entirely linear, with weak puzzles that feel more like chores than anything.  Story: 7/10 The story at times is rather generic, however at other points it is extemely engaging. Kind of a mixed bag here.  Overall: 7/10 Needs more depth, and difficulty.

After dealing with Owlboy for a full video series where I played it, it left a good impression on me as a game itself. Uncertain if I can link that, so here's just the review!  In all honesty, it's hard to rate Owlboy as anything less than 'Amazing' in almost every aspect it tries to touch upon. Gameplay is solid, the map is solid, the characters are great, the art is pretty and stylish, and the story overall is told well... But there are still flaws. In the story itself, there are a lot of things that are hamfisted or simply not explained well enough and most characters come off as negative because of that. Now, a majority of them are still fine and that's why I said they were great, but there are definitely a few I feel have fatal flaws that simply aren't explored in the gameplay. That is my major complaint.  Another major complaint is a build up that never receives a payoff. Something that may hint for things to come now that the foundation has been set, but... It could have been handled better. This game was amazing, there's no doubting that, and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who likes action platformers like this that are very story driven. There's also a lot of hidden things that just aren't really focused on unless you really want to 100% the game, which is a plus. It's nice when a game likes to show you its story through actual work instead of just an hour long cutscene, though there are plenty of small cutscenes through this game as well.  Regardless, this game has flaws and a few major ones too, but it's not a bad game. Gameplay was simple, clean, and overall fun, but ultimately ended up becoming repetitive or just annoying, particuarlly in certain situations. The music was always on point, though, and there were only a few points where the art was an issue, particuarlly when dealing with enemies that have arkward hit boxxes or move a lot. That being said...  .. The information I have states the game took over 10 years to come out. In these 10 years, it got a lot of support and a lot of people were looking forward to it. In no way do I think anyone who did wish for it is disappointed and I am definitely not disappointed either in buying it... But it could have been better and I feel like 10 years was more than enough time to make it better. There's a lot of small things that really make this game just barely reach 'Amazing', but it's still amazing nontheless. I'm looking forward to more from this group and hopefully this game will allow them to see flaws they otherwise missed because of either lack of experience, or simply not trying to focus on fixing them. Hopefully it'll take less than 10 years next time, possibly for a sequel. The good: The pixel art and soundtrack are beautiful. The deeper story is interesting.  The bad: There are maybe 10 hours of gameplay here, especially if you spin to move faster, and the game doesn't lend too much to replay value. The cannon mini-game (and to a lesser extent one boss with a related control scheme) do not have well-explained controls, unlike the rest of the game, so they come off as 'cheap' or 'overly difficult.'  The ugly: Unless I'm missing something, there is no way out of 'The Loop.' The last secret I found involves an eerie conversation about 'The Loop' with a dead owl, and that's that. Last year's big indie game had a similar 'Loop' style deep story item, but its 'True Ending' allowed the player to escape it (and even suggested not playing the game afterwards, as it would negate the premise of that ending). I'm not saying 'be more like that game,' but it's kind of sad to end with the normal ending knowing what 'The Loop' implies.  Was it worth a 9-year development cycle? That's for the developers to decide. Was it worth $30 and 10 hours of my life? If you have the disposable income, sure. If not, grab it on a Steam Sale.  Update: Nominated for the write-in award 'Years of Dev, 10 Hours of Play' for fall 2016 Steam Sale.
